title: Boris Johnson ‘very confident’ MPs will vote for his Brexit deal
text:
He told a press conference this evening that he believes we are now in an ‘exciting’ time (Picture: Reuters)

Boris Johnson said he is ‘very confident’ that MPs will want to vote for his Brexit deal on Saturday.

He told a press conference that he believes we are now in an ‘exciting’ time after a ‘painful and divisive’ three and a half years trying to deliver the referendum result.

Speaking after EU leaders approved the deal, he said: ‘I want to stress that this is a great deal for our country, for the UK. I also believe it’s a very good deal for our friends in the EU.

‘We can come out of the EU as one United Kingdom. We can decide our future together, we can take back control of our money and our laws and be able to do free trade agreements around the world.

‘We can build now, after three and a half years, on our relations with our friends and partners in the EU.

‘It will be a very exciting period now to get to the positive side of that project.

‘I am very confident that when my colleagues in parliament study this agreement, that they will want to vote for it on Saturday.

‘This is our chance as democrats to get Brexit done and come out on October 31.

‘It has been long, painful and divisive. Now is the moment for us as a country to come together and get this thing done and to begin building a new and progressive partnership with our EU friends.

‘There’s a very good case for MPs across the Commons to respect the democratic view of the people. I don’t think there is any case for delay.’

His press conference follows comments made by Donald Tusk, Jean-Claude Juncker and Irish prime minister Leo Varadkar.

The EU said we would always be welcome to come back (Picture: Reuters)

Mr Tusk said the key change was Mr Johnson’s acceptance to have customs checks at the point of entry into Northern Ireland.

‘This compromise will allow us to avoid border checks between Ireland and Northern Ireland and will ensure the integrity of the single market. ‘The reality is that today we have a deal which allows us to avoid chaos and an atmosphere of conflict between the EU 27 and the United Kingdom,’ he said.

He added: ‘On a personal note, I feel sadness because I will always be a Remainer. I hope our British friends decide to return one day. Our door will always be open.’

Irish prime minister Leo Varadkar told the press conference that he had mixed feelings towards the end of negotiations. He said he was happy there would be no hard border between the north and south of Ireland – but regretful that Britain had chosen to go its separate ways.

‘I have learned two things about the EU while Taoiseach,’ he said. ‘The strength of the unity of the EU, how much we can achieve if the 27 work together with common objectives, a truly powerful force for good in the world.

Advertisement

“As the leader of a small nation I have felt enormous solidarity from my European partners, and I think it’s been demonstrated in the past few years is a union of peoples and one in which small states are protected.

‘I have mixed feelings today, I regret the UK is leaving but respect the decision to do so, like an old friend going on a journey without us, and we really hope it works out for them. There will always be a place at the table for them if they ever want to come back.

President of the European Commission Jean-Claude Juncker (R) and British Prime Minister Boris Johnson shake hands during a press conference today (Picture: EPA)

The decision now moves to the House of Commons for them to consider the agreement.

MPs now have two days to mull over the content of the new deal before a vote on Saturday.

However, Mr Johnson faces an uphill struggle as the DUP, Labour, the SNP and Lib Dems have all said they cannot support the new deal.

The EU Parliament will also need to ratify the agreement.
